em.notes: Used for oneself when younger or lower status; polite and modest choice.

anh.notes: Used to address slightly older males or oneself toward a younger person; expresses warmth or authority.

chị.notes: Used to address slightly older females; may sound formal if age gap is small.

tôi.notes: Neutral and safe for formal, business, or distant settings.

bạn.notes: Polite but impersonal in close relationships.

mình.notes: Used reciprocally among close friends or partners; signals equality and intimacy.

cô.notes: Used for women of parental generation or female teachers; conveys respect.

chú.notes: Used for men younger than your father; respectful but friendly tone.

bác.notes: Used for people older than one's parents; most respectful within parental generation.

ông.notes: Used for elderly men; respectful; self-reference possible among very old speakers.

bà.notes: Used for elderly women; conveys high respect.

con.notes: Used by children or younger people toward elders; also shows humility in respectful speech.

cháu.notes: Used toward much older people, or for addressing young relatives; highly deferential.

thầy.notes: Used for male teachers or mentors; highly respectful, similar to 'Sir'.

cậu.notes: Mother’s younger brother; also casual peer term in Northern dialects (pair with 'tớ').

tao.notes: Used among close friends or toward subordinates; rude if misused or in formal contexts.

mày.notes: Used toward close peers or inferiors; rude outside intimate or joking contexts.
